headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Yahoo! Q4 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marta Nichols. Ms. Nichols, you may begin.
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Yahoo! Q4 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marta Nichols. Ms. Nichols, you may begin.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Yahoo!'s Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today will be Carol Bartz, Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Morse, Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's call will con
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to Yahoo!'s Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today will be Carol Bartz, Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Morse, Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's call will contain forward-looking statements concerning matters such as our expected financial and operational performance, our marketing and product plans, cost initiatives, planned investments, technology improvements and corporate strategy as well as our expectations for the economy in general and online advertising in particular. Actual results may differ materially from the results predicted in our statements, and reported results should not be considered indicative of future performance. Potential risks and uncertainties that could cause our business and financial results to differ materially from our forward-looking statements are described in our Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on November 6, 2009, as well as in the earnings release included as Exhibit 99.1 to the Form 8-K we furnished today to the SEC.  All information discussed on this call is as of today, January 26, 2010, and Yahoo! does not intend and undertakes no duty to update this information to reflect future events or circumstances. On today's call, we'll also discuss some non-GAAP financial measures as we talk about the company's performance. These may include operating income before depreciation, amortization and stock-based compensation expense, which we'll refer to as operating cash flow; revenue excluding traffic acquisition costs, which we'll refer to as revenue ex-TAC, non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP net income per share. Reconciliations of those non-GAAP measures to the GAAP measures we consider most comparable can be found on our corporate website, info.yahoo.com under Investor Relations.We have prepared remarks that will last about 30 minutes. And then we'll have a brief Q&A session with Carol and Tim. And now I'd like to turn the call over to Carol.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marta, and welcome back. Okay, Good afternoon, and thanks, all of you for joining us. Today, we're going to briefly recap 2009 and the progress we made during the year. Significant change at Yahoo!, talk about our financial results in detail, addr
componenttext: Thanks, Marta, and welcome back. Okay, Good afternoon, and thanks, all of you for joining us. Today, we're going to briefly recap 2009 and the progress we made during the year. Significant change at Yahoo!, talk about our financial results in detail, address some of the key topics that interest for Yahoo! and our industry, and outline our strategy and some of our plans for 2010.I recently celebrated my one year anniversary with the company and what a ride it's been. In fact, I might say, I've made it through my first year with the company and it was a wonderful ride. Very bumpy, and frankly, like many other business leaders, I'm very, very glad it's over. But it was also a great opportunity to restructure, reset and position Yahoo! for the next era of growth. I view my first year at Yahoo! at three phases.  First, I took a look at our consumers and the experience we provide them. I realized that we had to invest in the products that users engaged with the most like the Homepage, Mail, Messenger, News, Sports, Finance, Entertainment. We also decided to close down products that didn't drive engagement or proudly represent Yahoo!. In that same thing, I even asked employees to sign their names next to projects they've done and if they can't, then they need to go back and make it right, so that they'll be proud of what they deliver.The second phase, was listen to advertisers. Working to improve our relationships with them and to continue to deliver quality data, insights and innovative ad platforms. With 600 million users on Yahoo! branded sites, we are one of the largest, most valuable and highest-quality audiences on the Internet. And we're constantly coming up with new ways to connect advertisers with the consumers they see.Then came the third phase. I really started to focus on how we generate value. For us, it's a vast amount of data we gather and use to deliver a better, more personal experience for users, and a better, more targeted audience for our advertisers. Just look at our Homepage, for example. Since we began pairing our content optimization technology with editorial expertise, we've seen click-through rates in the today module more than double. And we're making additional improvements to this technology that will make the user experience even more personally relevant. While we have extremely sophisticated technology and brilliant scientists powering these efforts, we've been letting great data about the consumers, data that's very attractive to advertisers, fall to the floor. We're the leader in targeting in insights, but we simply aren't even close to maximizing the value of our massive audience for advertisers.Truth be told, no one has uncovered the Holy Grail of making advertising as relevant as content is 100% of the time. Beyond just offering advertisers a specific bucket, say women age 35 to 45 that have children, we instead need to deliver many more specific attributes to the scale. For example, women aged 35 to 45 with kids under three who's shopping for minivans, and on and on and on and on. If we can do this, we can create a better experience for both the user and the advertiser.Meanwhile, of course, we're also taking steps to improve consumer privacy and transparency online. Last month, we launched our Ad Interest Manager that allows users to select how we serve ads to them on our network. So that was '09. Along the way, we made progress in many areas. We reset the management team and reorganized the company. We launched the new Homepage and a suite of great mobile products and apps. We refreshed Mail, Messenger and some of our other key properties. We introduced new ad products, and upgraded existing platforms to drive improved advertiser ROI. And I'll talk more about that in a minute. And of course, we signed a Search agreement with Microsoft.We did all of these during one of the worst economic climates ever, most of the S&P 500 suffered with declining revenue last year, and that includes many of our largest customers. In that light, Yahoo!'s revenue decline of only 10% is pretty darn good. Compare that with traditional media who are really struggling and we all hold up well. After the fourth quarter, things definitely began to pick up. We beat our overall revenue guidance range and displayed strength sequentially, growing 26% from Q3. In fact, the number of our premium properties, including the Homepage, sold out due to high demand from top brand advertisers.Meanwhile, Search revenue continued to stabilize and then some.  We actually grew all in all Search revenue sequentially in Q4 for the first time since Q3 '08. Overall, things seem to be returning to a more normal state in the Online Ad business. But let me be clear, these results are not just the result of the improving economic climate. These are the direct result of hard work that culminated in Q4 and would continue into this year and beyond. Now, Tim,  Let's take a more in-depth look of our financial performance.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Carol. We're pleased with our fourth quarter performance. Revenue came in above the top end of our guidance range, as did operating income excluding restructuring and Microsoft-related costs. We saw a strong demand in our core Display and Se
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Carol. We're pleased with our fourth quarter performance. Revenue came in above the top end of our guidance range, as did operating income excluding restructuring and Microsoft-related costs. We saw a strong demand in our core Display and Search marketplaces in 4Q. And we believe that the ad market recovery is underway. Diving right into the detailed results, revenue was $1.732 billion for the quarter. While this was a 4% decrease from 2008, it was up 10% sequentially, which is our best 4Q sequential performance in several years.  As the economy seems to be gaining a firmer footing and ad budgets are recovering, Yahoo! continues to be the place that marketers come for unique high-quality ad placements that are scarce on the Internet.O&O Display was essentially flat year-over-year, which was a big improvement compared to where we were earlier in '09. But the best news was that Display grew an impressive 26% sequentially. 4Q is of course a seasonally strong quarter, but this year's sequential growth was the strongest we've seen since 2006.Drilling into the components of Display revenue, our guaranteed inventory performed very well in the quarter and continued to increase as a percent of total Display revenue. Demand was strong throughout the quarter and several of our key placements were sold out. Pricing recovered this quarter after a challenging 2009 with guaranteed pricing for some of our most important properties returning to fourth quarter 2008 levels. The strength we saw on the guaranteed side also improved the performance of our non-guaranteed inventory. Advertisers bid up the price of non-guaranteed placements due to the scarce availability of premium guaranteed buys. Of the major advertiser categories that we track in Display, nine out of 10 grew sequentially. Year-over-year, half were up and half were down. The Retail Consumer Products and Telecom segments grew strongly compared to last year. Autos was about flat and Entertainment and Finance declined year-over-year offsetting the growth in the stronger categories.Turning to Search, there's encouraging news to report as well. Compared to last year, we registered a revenue decline of 15% on query growth of greater than 10% globally in mid-single digits in the U.S. More importantly, on a sequential basis, we grew revenue by 4% the first time we've done so since the third quarter of 2008.  The primary drivers of fourth quarter performance were improvements to our Matching Algorithms that yielded better than expected positive results, including an 8% sequential increase in global revenue per search. Just last week, we also introduced network distribution, a search platform enhancement that enables advertisers to more precisely tune their keyword bids to maximize ROI and we believe this will further improve our O&O RPS in 2010. Compared to last quarter, eight of our 10 advertiser categories grew. Year-over-year, Entertainment, Consumer Products, Health and Telecom were the growth leaders for the quarter while Travel and Finance were relatively weak.Before moving on, let's take a moment to put our Search business in perspective. Search is an important part of Yahoo!  And growing Search revenue is a key company priority. We're focused on pulling both the volume and monetization levers to improve results. On the volume side, we're using a combination of product enhancements, search-oriented marketing spending and the power of the Yahoo! network as a Search distribution channel to reaccelerate query volume. On monetization, I mentioned the matching technologies we've recently brought into the marketplace that benefited RPS. And that's just the first step of an aggressive road map of monetization enhancements we'll execute upon.Returning to the quarterly highlights, the Affiliate business outpaced our overall growth rate in 4Q and in fact grew year-over-year. Some of this growth was attributable to favorable currency fluctuations, but we also benefited from signing new partners. Our 4Q signing of DOM in South Korea, which we won back from Google is evidence of our ability to compete for these deals.Transitioning to profitability, GAAP operating income was $119 million. This includes $32 million in cost related to our search agreement with Microsoft and $40 million in lingering restructuring charges without which we would have been well above the high end of our guidance range. OCF was $404 million including $21 million of cash restructuring charges and $32 million of Microsoft-related costs. This is the last time we plan to report OCF. As I mentioned at Investor Day, operating income is our key profitability metric.Operating costs landed within our expected range for fourth quarter enabling strong flow-through of incremental revenue to the bottom line. We are working hard to maximize the productivity of our spending and our business also has great operating leverage which will benefit us during the economic recovery. We exited the quarter with 13,900 employees which was an increase of about 700 from our 3Q level, including about 250 employees from two acquisitions. About a third of those new hires were in product development and the balance was in sales and marketing.Turning to the balance sheet, we ended 2009 with $4.5 billion of cash and marketable debt securities. During the fourth quarter, we invested $170 million in CapEx and repurchased $23 million of stock. At the end of the quarter, the pretax value of our 35% stake in Yahoo! Japan and our 29% indirect stake in Alibaba.com was $9.5 billion, or nearly $6.75 per share. These figures are based on public market quotes and do not include estimates of the value of Alibaba Group's privately held businesses.Looking ahead to 2010, we expect first quarter revenue in the range of $1,575,000,000 to $1,675,000,000. This reflects seasonality on a sequential basis and 3% year-over-year growth at the midpoint despite the short-term negative impact of our revenue quality initiatives. It's also noteworthy that a return to top line growth will be our first since the third quarter of 2008.To round out revenue guidance, traffic acquisition costs should be 28% to 29% of GAAP revenue. We also expect 1Q operating income in the range of $90 million to $110 million, including depreciation and amortization of roughly $170 million and stock-based compensation of about $95 million. This guidance excludes advisory and retention costs related to the Microsoft agreement and any restructuring charges related to our ongoing cost initiatives.Briefly touching on total year 2010, we expect to grow revenue including both O&O Search and Display. And we plan to expand GAAP margins. For the year, our effective tax rate should be in the 35% to 40% range and our CapEx spending between $600 million and $700 million. As a reminder on the Microsoft deal, we don't expect revenue sharing to begin in 2010, but once the deal closes we'll start to get reimbursements from Microsoft for the cost of running our Algo and Paid Search businesses. For 2011 and 2012, we'll start to share revenue as the Paid Search businesses combined by region. We'll provide further guidance on the revenue sharing, cost reimbursement and timing of the $150 million of payments from Microsoft as well as the financial statement presentation of all these items after we begin implementation.Before I turn the call back to Carol, I'd like to reiterate some of our 2010 financial priorities. First, we'll continue to invest for growth. As we proved in 4Q, this business has strong operating leverage. So we need to seize every opportunity to grow the top line. That means investments to accelerate share shift, improvements to our advertising and analytics platforms and continuing investment in our key audience properties. Whether this is via internal development or through M&A activity, we're positioning Yahoo! for its next phase of growth.Second, we will continue to simplify and streamline Yahoo! to drive margin expansion and ROIC that exceeds our cost of capital. As I outlined at Investor Day, our goal was to generate 15% to 20% operating margins and 15 % to 20% ROIC by 2012. As a point of reference, our operating margin for 2009 was 6% and our ROIC was 5%. The Microsoft deal will improve the economics of our Search business, which will free up resources for investment in other areas of the company. We believe the combination of investments for future growth, more efficient operations and Microsoft-related savings will enable us to significantly improve Yahoo!'s financial performance. We're building an execution machine here and you'll start to see that emerge even more during 2010.Third and final, we're committed to transparency and consistency. Given some of the complexities of the Microsoft deal, we'll be making extra efforts to help you understand the run rate of the business versus the effects of the various interim steps of the Search transaction. I look forward to reporting back to you on our progress throughout the year. And with that, I'll hand the call back to Carol.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Now I'd like to talk to you about a few things that are top of mind. First up, let's talk about Display Advertising. While many of you didn't believe me, I kept saying throughout 2009 that brand advertising would come back. It always has. Dem
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. Now I'd like to talk to you about a few things that are top of mind. First up, let's talk about Display Advertising. While many of you didn't believe me, I kept saying throughout 2009 that brand advertising would come back. It always has. Demand for our guaranteed display inventory is growing. We're seeing advertisers reach farther into 2010 to book premium Yahoo! sites and events so we expect the positive momentum to keep building.We have some of the best, if not the best premium inventory on the Internet. Advertisers are competing for it now that their businesses are getting healthier and larger budgets are finding their way back into the hands of CMOs. As these market shares look to position new products and brands in the marketplace, they'll need Display Ads to tell their stories. You can't position a brand with keywords.And as a result of better guaranteed sell-through in Q4, the obvious happened. Non-guaranteed demand also shut up during the quarter. Because we made significant improvements the Right Media platform last year, we were able to respond to this increased demand without a hitch. We are now delivering relevant audiences at scale, faster and more accurately than ever before.In addition to Right Media, we've done a tremendous amount of work on all of our ads, products, systems and analytics. For example, we introduced and implemented innovative new format such as Rich Ads in Search, and we've got many more new products planned for this year. We are also working on our relationship with advertisers. This includes making Yahoo! easier to do business with and being a better creative partner, while delivering the insights that helped marketers managed great campaign. And much of what we're working on this year, will allow advertisers to buy specific targeted audience at huge scale. They'll increasingly be able to measure their online advertising with the same kind of consistent, easy-to-use tool they use for off-line media.By the way, we're still ahead of the display game and we intend to keep it that way. Frankly, our competition is television. That's where major advertisers spend most of their money and where we're taking share. As a result, video is becoming increasingly important. It's now an area where we lead in the concept of video snacks. Our TV recap show, Primetime in No Time is one of the most streamed shows on the web. It attracts millions of streams each month, and even hit 12 million streams in one day in November. That's bigger than the TV audience who turned in to the recent season premiere of 24. But we're only getting started. Our recently announced partnership with GroupM and Electus expand our capability in this space. The partnership with Electus, Electus for example, brings heavy-hitting Hollywood firepower to Yahoo! through Ben Silverman, an Emmy and Golden Globe winning producer. He's been behind top shows like The Office, 30 Rock and more. We're excited about this because Ben and his team understand the power of Yahoo!'s audience. We give Electus massive reach but remember, we are not trying to mimic traditional TV format. We are about developing low-cost, high-quality Web content for our users that's created in partnership with advertisers.Another subject we're asked about a lot is Social, usually in the context of Facebook and Twitter. We are happy to say that we're partnering with Facebook to deliver familiar social experiences within the Yahoo! network and to enable simpler, broader sharing of great Yahoo! content as well. We view both Social and Video as features that should not exist in a silo. There are features that should be tightly integrated into all of Yahoo! properties as a way to expand and enhance the user experience.So that's Display, Video and Social. But we also have a very important Search business. And after the Microsoft deal was implemented, it's a business that we believe will become even more powerful and profitable while delivering a more engaging and relevant user experience. Yahoo! Search is also picking up steam. Last quarter, our O&O Search revenue grew 4% versus Q3, the first sequential increase since Q3 '08.Our combination of ad solutions across Search and Display is a great competitive advantage, and Search is an obvious part of our overall success. As Tim said, we did very well on the RPS side last quarter. Our work on monetization will continue, even as we now aggressively tackle Search volume. Search is a top priority for us. We recently hired Shashi Seth, an expert in the Search industry to lead our efforts. Our dedication to improving the Search experience and accelerating volume growth will be very visible. We've already made significant changes to our Search Ad capability to capture more value from queries. In 2009, we built on our dynamic pricing abilities, continue to optimize the way we served Search Ads based on user behavior, enabled advertisers to port Search campaigns from Google and other engines directly into Yahoo!, and rolled out substantially better matching technology. These efforts drove up RPS in Q4, and we have even more on the road map this year.We are also focused on consumer engagement and Search volume. For instance, we have a new breaking new shortcut. Search a news item like Haiti and you'll get multiple tabs with results from all over the web and the best of Yahoo! network, including news, photos, video and Twitter feeds. We'll also market Search on and off the Yahoo! network, implementing new toolbar and browser offers and launch other great new features. Using our leading Homepage, Mail and Messenger products, and key media verticals, we can effectively market our Search capabilities to people who are already no and love Yahoo!. But we won't stop there. We've done a great job so far revitalizing the Yahoo! brand with our marketing campaign, and Search will be a key ingredient of the message as we now shift to more product-centric advertising.Mobile is generating a lot of browse right now. So I want to spend a few minutes talking about our strategy. Users clearly expect to have access to the same kind of services they use on the PC but designed for their mobile phones, and they want to interactive with brands they know and trust. Our strategy is to grow and monetize the Yahoo! audience on Mobile. To do this, we're focused on building great experiences that our users love, our Mobile Homepage, Mail, Messenger, Finance, Flickr and Fantasy Sports. Today, people in 187 countries use our Mobile Internet services. And we've been developing these experiences across thousands of handsets, including high-end devices like the iPhone, BlackBerry and soon, Android.Mobile monetization is in the early stages for everyone right now, but it's growing quickly for us. We're having the Mobile advertising discussion with our biggest clients every day. In fact, we've recently signed one of the largest Mobile ad buys ever with a major auto manufacturer.Partners continue to be an important part of our Mobile strategy. We are a trusted partner in this space, and we work with more than 100 OEMs and carriers to help distribute our products. We're looking to partner with the right players and ecosystem, who can help us reach the largest number of engaged users.Moving on, I know another topic of interest is what we're going to buy and what we're going to sell. As you probably heard, we recently signed an agreement to sell Zimbra to VMware. We'll continue to look at other parts of the business, for divestiture, partnerships or outsourcing could generate incremental value and help us improve our focus. But 2010 is not about divestitures for Yahoo!. Sure, there might be a few, but they'll be an ongoing part of our business just like it is for any other company. For us, 2010 is about acquisitions and investments to make Yahoo! even stronger.We think about acquisitions in three buckets. The first is the small to medium acquisitions where we acquire important technology and the people behind it. The second is content-related, where we acquire a company for their audience, content or community. There a lot of niche sites that have highly-engaged users and specialty content that would fit well with our portfolio and our advertiser needs. And third is geographic, where we will make an acquisition to move into or strengthen markets, like our deal with Maktoob. What we don't have is any current plans for big acquisition, peer-to-peer type plays because they seldom create value.Tim and I both know that success in acquisitions isn't much about integration and performance measurements as it is about negotiating deals. Yahoo! hasn't always focused well on post-deal accountability, but you can be sure that we're committed to it now.So what's ahead for us this year? We're done looking inward, we're looking outward at the incredible opportunities ahead and are focused on the following areas: Great experiences for our consumers, including a more social, mobile and video features and improved local context; super serving the largest Display advertisers with our impressive region frequency, insights and analytics, and of course, ROI; continuing to grow our Search business with a focus on volume and revenue improvements; moving forward with the Search deal with Microsoft; and of course, continuing to drive operational excellence throughout the company to drive margin expansion.So that's where we've been and where we're going, but we're just getting started and we're feeling good heading into 2010. We look forward to telling you more about our progress next quarter and at our next Investor Day, which will be late May. Moving forward, we'll meet each spring to update you on our business. So please save May 26 on your calendar, and we'll get to more details to you very soon. With that, I'd like to open up the call to questions. Operator?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Imran Khan from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Imran Khan from JPMorgan.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a one housekeeping question and then a real question. So the housekeeping question is, could you give us some sense how much of your revenue was infected because of cleanup this quarter? And I think the last quarter you've talked about $240 million
componenttext: I have a one housekeeping question and then a real question. So the housekeeping question is, could you give us some sense how much of your revenue was infected because of cleanup this quarter? And I think the last quarter you've talked about $240 million impact, $60 million per quarter because of cleanup. Do you still think that you will have that kind of impact? And then the real question for Carol, I think, recently, some of the publishers are talking about how they will take back some of their inventory from the ad network. And a couple of years ago, giving that kind of inventories to ad network had a significant pressure on that pricing. So as you think about the Display advertising growth next year, obviously, the economic improvement will help. How do you think this pulling inventory away from ad network that some of other publishers are doing will infect the industry?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So what we'd originally guided to was third quarter was about $15 million going to $25 million of the ad quality initiatives. Instead of the $25 million, I'd say it came in less than half that. I mean, the plain truth is we great backfill. You saw it in b
componenttext: So what we'd originally guided to was third quarter was about $15 million going to $25 million of the ad quality initiatives. Instead of the $25 million, I'd say it came in less than half that. I mean, the plain truth is we great backfill. You saw it in both our guaranteed and our non-guaranteed side. So I think that work out really well. We had also previously guided that we go from a $25 million in the fourth quarter to $60 million. I think we will and that's about $35 million more of impact for the last installment of these initiatives. I think it's probably a little bit less than that, but probably still in that $30 million range from fourth quarter to first quarter. So overall, I'd say because of the backfill, because some of this investment is bearing fruit a little more quickly than we had even hoped, then I'd say the total impact of these initiatives, instead of $240 million, I'd put it at, well, south of $200 million, maybe even something like $150 million.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the exchange question is called or the inventories question is called, I think there are still a lot of moving parts. First of all, I think we have great relationships with most of the content providers out there. We also, right now, have the la
componenttext: As far as the exchange question is called or the inventories question is called, I think there are still a lot of moving parts. First of all, I think we have great relationships with most of the content providers out there. We also, right now, have the largest exchange in Right Media. We have 120,000 active buyers and sellers. So there would have to be a major shift to cause any kind of a problem with Display inventory. We're focusing on quality, we're focusing on quality partners. And as far as I'm concerned, I don't see any platonic shift coming anytime soon.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sandeep Aggarwal from Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sandeep Aggarwal from Collins Stewart.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First question on the page views, we saw the continuation of decline in the page views. Can you let me know by when we can expect a pick up in page views' growth and especially in the back drop of global ad campaign you launched in September?
componenttext: First question on the page views, we saw the continuation of decline in the page views. Can you let me know by when we can expect a pick up in page views' growth and especially in the back drop of global ad campaign you launched in September?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk a little bit about page views and you can, too, as well. A lot of the metrics people are starting to back away from page views because there's a lot happening. For instance, a lot of the technology we're putting on our pages now drive page vie
componenttext: Let me talk a little bit about page views and you can, too, as well. A lot of the metrics people are starting to back away from page views because there's a lot happening. For instance, a lot of the technology we're putting on our pages now drive page views away, whether that's streaming quotes our what have you. So we're actually trying to look at as much as anything as engagement. Frankly, what we're really trying to look at is just really great revenue growth because we deliver such good quality insights to our ad partners. We'll look [ph] (34:34) in engagement because you guys look in engagement. But seriously, it really is about taking these $600 million uniques and the engagement, which is already number one on the Internet to time spent, to delivering just great revenue and insights for us and our CMOs. As far as the impact on the ad campaign, it's been out there three months now. It has sort of two real different vectors. The vector in the U.S. is not to grow users, but it's to change attitudes and behavior and to sort of reacquaint them with the Yahoo! brand and position it in places like India and the parts of Europe. It's to not only engage, but to get known better and to grow. And we've seen both things happen, even though three months is way, way too soon to judge any ad campaign. The other thing I mentioned on the prepared remarks, that I'd like to repeat, is the campaign will now be moving to a product focus: Products around promoting Search, promoting Homepage, promoting Mail, Messenger, that sort of thing. And this will be online media, mostly not TV. The first was just to wake people up about the fact that Yahoo! is interesting and an exciting brand, change their attitudes about us, and now we roll on into introducing them to our wonderful product sets.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Schachter from Broadpoint AmTech.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Schachter from Broadpoint AmTech.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment on where the streams is coming from for the affiliates, and how will the network distribution bidding change impact that going forward? And just on a housekeeping, if you could just comment on the comp score Search sha
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on where the streams is coming from for the affiliates, and how will the network distribution bidding change impact that going forward? And just on a housekeeping, if you could just comment on the comp score Search share numbers: A, could you tell us, do you think they're accurate; b, how much of this is toolbars and where do you think that number bottom?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: On the first question, the affiliate strength was really two parts, as I said in my script. It's the currency impact of translation of the foreign currencies and it was the win back specifically of DOM in South Korea, so those two really make up just abou
componenttext: On the first question, the affiliate strength was really two parts, as I said in my script. It's the currency impact of translation of the foreign currencies and it was the win back specifically of DOM in South Korea, so those two really make up just about the whole increase. On the second question, in terms of Search, we're not going to comment on comp scores numbers. Toolbar is obviously important, but we're focused on our O&O, on O&O distribution. So if you look at our Search volume, we grew it over 10% globally year-over-year for fourth quarter. We think that's pretty good, but clearly we want to do better and better and better. I devoted some space in my script to this topic and so did Carol. This is a key priority for the company, so you can absolutely look for us to be very active in the space of actively increasing our volume.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Plus to make sure that through quality-based pricing that the advertisers get great content. A theme that will be driving home continuously is to have a great neighborhood. Advertisers trust us, our users trust us and we want to always make sure we have a
componenttext: Plus to make sure that through quality-based pricing that the advertisers get great content. A theme that will be driving home continuously is to have a great neighborhood. Advertisers trust us, our users trust us and we want to always make sure we have a great neighborhood.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I didn't address that part of the question. The network distribution, clearly, will have pricing gravitate towards the highest quality sites, and we believe that's where we play extremely well. And frankly, it gives everybody else the opportunity to
componenttext: Yes, I didn't address that part of the question. The network distribution, clearly, will have pricing gravitate towards the highest quality sites, and we believe that's where we play extremely well. And frankly, it gives everybody else the opportunity to improve their own quality as well and see it reflected in their RPS. So I think it's good for everybody.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney from Citigroup.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I had two housekeeping questions. First had to do with the margin outlook for Q1, and I know it's just a quarter, I know there's negative seasonality or it's a weaker seasonal quarter. But that 6% operating margin, I know that's not what your long-term go
componenttext: I had two housekeeping questions. First had to do with the margin outlook for Q1, and I know it's just a quarter, I know there's negative seasonality or it's a weaker seasonal quarter. But that 6% operating margin, I know that's not what your long-term goal is. Were there any costs that are going to be unusual in that quarter, anything that slipped from Q4 into Q1? And then secondly, Carol, could you talk a little bit about international and where you want to bring out the best improvements or where are you weakest now that you want to really boost your strength? And where are you most happy with your progress to date internationally?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, what you have is essentially the confluence of two bad seasonal effects. Number one, it's a seasonally down quarter in terms of our top line and it's a seasonally up quarter in terms of many of our costs, especially in the benefi
componenttext: So on the first question, what you have is essentially the confluence of two bad seasonal effects. Number one, it's a seasonally down quarter in terms of our top line and it's a seasonally up quarter in terms of many of our costs, especially in the benefits and compensation area. You have payroll taxes, you have the way vacation accrual accounting works and the likes. So you'll see, usually, a spike up in the costs in the first quarter and then a downdraft on them in compensation for the rest of the year, excluding obviously the impact of any headcount hires. So it's really the mix of those two different things. We certainly, we've excluded any transition costs related to Microsoft, any restructuring charges and there's nothing else that kind of missed the fourth and went into the first. I think overall if you look at our cost structure on a normalized basis fourth quarter was about $800 million and for just that short-term piece of OpEx, what we used to call cash costs and this quarter, it's maybe a little bit less than $800 million. So were taking an awful lot down in order to just make room for the benefits and the payroll taxes, et cetera, that will naturally increase in the first quarter. And then we'll continue to improve our cost position, we believe and reinvest in the business to reallocate costs of more growth areas as we go through the year and beyond. So that's kind of how I'd look at that guidance.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, as far as international is concerned, most happy with our performance in the Asia Rim. We have great market share, great penetration. Least happy with, I would say, if I have to pick a country Germany it's such a big economy and we really don't do w
componenttext: Mark, as far as international is concerned, most happy with our performance in the Asia Rim. We have great market share, great penetration. Least happy with, I would say, if I have to pick a country Germany it's such a big economy and we really don't do well there. There's a long history behind that. Spain would be another one obviously not as important as Germany. But where we're going to focus is where the big Internet populations are coming online, Indonesia, India, Brazil, Mexico, the obvious. In some of the smaller markets like Vietnam, we have a great penetration. But just think of us as following Internet users coming online and that's why, of course, Mobile is so important to us.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer & Co.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer & Co.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow back up on the marketing point. Do you have any kind of metrics you can share with us relating to the homepage as to what the positive impact was of the marketing campaign? But then when you think about that kind of that longer term
componenttext: I just want to follow back up on the marketing point. Do you have any kind of metrics you can share with us relating to the homepage as to what the positive impact was of the marketing campaign? But then when you think about that kind of that longer term growing traffic and usage to the homepage, do think that will help improve the search trends?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So talking about the homepage, of course we gave you a bit of an update at the Analyst Day. Usage continues to grow faster than the rest of the Yahoo! Network. We're very happy with the content optimization in the Today module. We have doubled our click t
componenttext: So talking about the homepage, of course we gave you a bit of an update at the Analyst Day. Usage continues to grow faster than the rest of the Yahoo! Network. We're very happy with the content optimization in the Today module. We have doubled our click through rate because the content is more engaging relative to what's happening that day. We also have a 200% click through increase in the local part of the news. So that's really important, especially as we focus on local. Some things we didn't get right, in fact we're going to remove the hovers tonight. It just so happened it wasn't for you guys, but it just so happened that there were enough people we were driving crazy and enough advertisers we were driving crazy because we were covering their ads. So we listened and in fact, that's coming off tonight. The goal of the marketing campaign wasn't in the first part, wasn't behavior-driven especially the U.S., it was just about awareness of what Yahoo! is. And so we're just happy with what's happening in the homepage. To me that's separate from what's happening with the ad campaign.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And I just add that if you look at the ad campaign itself and you've kind of pan out, we're spending somewhere between 1% and 1.5% of revenue on that brand awareness which is right in line. Maybe is still even a little bit low compared to large technology
componenttext: And I just add that if you look at the ad campaign itself and you've kind of pan out, we're spending somewhere between 1% and 1.5% of revenue on that brand awareness which is right in line. Maybe is still even a little bit low compared to large technology companies and definitely low versus the benchmarks we have for other Internet companies. So just to put them in perspective that way.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Mitchell from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Mitchell from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I was a little bit surprised that the Entertainment revenue on the Display O&O side was down year-on-year. Do you think that you're seeing more competition for that vertical from pure play rivals such as YouTube?
componenttext: I was a little bit surprised that the Entertainment revenue on the Display O&O side was down year-on-year. Do you think that you're seeing more competition for that vertical from pure play rivals such as YouTube?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, that isn't what we think at all. Entertainment always tends to be kind of lumpy. It depends on a lot on what movies are coming out and so forth. In this particular quarter, believe it or not, because of all of the pre-buzz, Avatar didn't think i
componenttext: Actually, that isn't what we think at all. Entertainment always tends to be kind of lumpy. It depends on a lot on what movies are coming out and so forth. In this particular quarter, believe it or not, because of all of the pre-buzz, Avatar didn't think it needed to have that much of an online budget. So even something as simple as that will drive Entertainment. And it wasn't down all that much anyway, but we don't think it's anything to do with competition. We think it's more to do with just a seasonal ad spend.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And interestingly, Entertainment was down year-over-year on the Display side, but it was up reasonably strongly on the Search side. So I don't know what you make of it, to be honest. It's not statistically significant.
componenttext: And interestingly, Entertainment was down year-over-year on the Display side, but it was up reasonably strongly on the Search side. So I don't know what you make of it, to be honest. It's not statistically significant.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from line of Justin Post from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Justin Post from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: One question and then one calculation question. First, you gained 3% growth in the first quarter and I think O&O was down 9% in the fourth quarter. So do you see sequentially a getting better to the point that O&O is kind of matching your overall growth r
componenttext: One question and then one calculation question. First, you gained 3% growth in the first quarter and I think O&O was down 9% in the fourth quarter. So do you see sequentially a getting better to the point that O&O is kind of matching your overall growth rate or is there any kind of abnormal affiliate activity in the first quarter? And then secondly, on the EBITDA calculation, starting from the bottoms up and adding in the $170 million depreciation and the $95 million in SBC [stock-based compensation], we get to $3.55 to $3.75. I'm just wondering if that build is correct.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, we're not going to break out O&O versus affiliates in our guidance. We always give you that detail when we get to the end of the quarter, but we're not going to go there for guidance. And on OCF mass, I'd encourage you to follow-
componenttext: So on the first question, we're not going to break out O&O versus affiliates in our guidance. We always give you that detail when we get to the end of the quarter, but we're not going to go there for guidance. And on OCF mass, I'd encourage you to follow-up. I'm just not going to talk about OCF. That's not our metric, we're moving away from it, it's operating income. If you're $90 million to $110 million in operating income and I give you the other two numbers, I think it's pretty straight forward. But just rather not talk about it because we're really moving away.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth from Barclays Capital.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things on the Search side, a few new initiatives that I was hoping you could talk about. First one is network quality scores, which I think started maybe late 3Q or early in the 4Q. And then also if you could talk about network distribution mo
componenttext: A couple of things on the Search side, a few new initiatives that I was hoping you could talk about. First one is network quality scores, which I think started maybe late 3Q or early in the 4Q. And then also if you could talk about network distribution more in 2010. What do you think the impact of that is going to be? And then also in your TAC rate for 1Q, I think the 28% to 29% seems relatively high versus what we've seen over the last couple of years. So just curious if there's anything in particular we should keep in mind here, perhaps, other than the down deal coming back?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We actually think that in network distribution, that it really is going to have a very positive impact on Search. It's just starting so I don't want to just forecast a specific feature or operation, but it's part of a lot of efforts that we have going on.
componenttext: We actually think that in network distribution, that it really is going to have a very positive impact on Search. It's just starting so I don't want to just forecast a specific feature or operation, but it's part of a lot of efforts that we have going on. We took our eye off the ball a little bit this summer as we were all digesting on helping the teams here digest the Microsoft situation. And then we went full bore back in the development to make sure that we really added to our Search quality for both the advertisers, as well as, real honest to God, ROI through, again, we talked about matching and so forth. So there's a whole lot that we'll probably even be able to talk about on Analyst Day that we've been focusing on, so I don't want to just pull out one area.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I would add to that before going to the TAC question is, if you look at quality-based pricing, you look at network distribution, it's really just the next in the evolution in providing best pricing for traffic quality. I mean, that's where it
componenttext: I guess what I would add to that before going to the TAC question is, if you look at quality-based pricing, you look at network distribution, it's really just the next in the evolution in providing best pricing for traffic quality. I mean, that's where it's at. And the goal of the quality scores is to take the quality-based pricing and the network distribution and increase advertiser ROI. So we think matching pricing with the highest quality traffic is great for us and increasing advertiser ROI is, obviously, great for advertisers.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And one more thing back to network distribution. This is part of a series of visibility analytics that we will be giving our advertisers to really manage campaigns the way they want to manage the campaigns. One of the things that Yahoo! has been a little
componenttext: And one more thing back to network distribution. This is part of a series of visibility analytics that we will be giving our advertisers to really manage campaigns the way they want to manage the campaigns. One of the things that Yahoo! has been a little light on is the tools in analytics and things in front of the curtain instead of the Wizard of Oz behind the curtain, so you will see us continue to focus on that a lot.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Doug, quickly on your TAC question, if you look at first quarter year-over-year for TAC, it was just shy of 27% last year. There's an increase in the FX rates that we anticipate if everything holds of about 7/10 of a percent, so that will take y
componenttext: And then, Doug, quickly on your TAC question, if you look at first quarter year-over-year for TAC, it was just shy of 27% last year. There's an increase in the FX rates that we anticipate if everything holds of about 7/10 of a percent, so that will take you kind in the mid-27.5%. So from there, you're seeing a little bit of mix of geography, a little bit of rates that have developed over the course of the last year. I've talked about that on a couple of calls that there's definitely been a little bit of pressure on TAC rates. But what you'll see is somewhere in this range for most of the quarters, and then on the fourth quarter, it kind of flushes downward like you saw last year. So overall, that's kind of how we look at the TAC rate. But there's nothing necessarily unusual going on in the first quarter, especially year-over-year.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Brian Pitz from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Brian Pitz from UBS.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Based on your prior experience migrating advertisers to Panama, can you give us a sense of the advertiser churn that you expect from the transition to Microsoft? And then second, unrelated, would you provide any additional detail on RPS growth between bot
componenttext: Based on your prior experience migrating advertisers to Panama, can you give us a sense of the advertiser churn that you expect from the transition to Microsoft? And then second, unrelated, would you provide any additional detail on RPS growth between both U.S. and international?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, I'm not really an expert on advertiser churn. I wasn't here for Panama. The inquiry that I've done just on a high level because, of course, I'm obviously interested in making sure that this transition goes right. But from what I've been told, wi
componenttext: You know, I'm not really an expert on advertiser churn. I wasn't here for Panama. The inquiry that I've done just on a high level because, of course, I'm obviously interested in making sure that this transition goes right. But from what I've been told, without specifics, is it actually went very well. We were very careful about managing it marketplace-by-marketplace so that advertisers felt there was a working market by the time they got over to the other platform. So I think we know how to do this. Of course, Chi [ph] (51:59) knows how to do this on the other side, on the Microsoft side. So nobody has put in the red flags in front of me, Brian, I think that's the easiest way to say it.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then on the other part, international versus U.S. RPS, we saw advances in both. It was stronger in the U.S., but we saw advances both in international and U.S. quarter-over-quarter.
componenttext: Yes, and then on the other part, international versus U.S. RPS, we saw advances in both. It was stronger in the U.S., but we saw advances both in international and U.S. quarter-over-quarter.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And by the way, that kind of stands to reason because the features roll in to the U.S. platform first. And so this technology, including the matching technology we talked about, is not yet available internationally, as an example. So that will be somethin
componenttext: And by the way, that kind of stands to reason because the features roll in to the U.S. platform first. And so this technology, including the matching technology we talked about, is not yet available internationally, as an example. So that will be something that will be benefiting in '10.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Kessler from Standard & Poor's Equity.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Kessler from Standard & Poor's Equity.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Some questions have been asked and answered related to international. I was wondering if you could provide an update about your search for a new leader within that organization? Obviously, it's been the better part of the year since I think we've had some
componenttext: Some questions have been asked and answered related to international. I was wondering if you could provide an update about your search for a new leader within that organization? Obviously, it's been the better part of the year since I think we've had someone in place, and just looking for some details.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I actually announced internally a couple of weeks ago that I have decided to re-org the international arena into three regions: EMEA, so that's Europe; Middle East; Africa; Asia PAC, which is everything over to India; and the Americas which, of cours
componenttext: Yes, I actually announced internally a couple of weeks ago that I have decided to re-org the international arena into three regions: EMEA, so that's Europe; Middle East; Africa; Asia PAC, which is everything over to India; and the Americas which, of course, sweeps in South America. And therefore, to not have a emerging market standalone anymore and instead they have all three regions report directly in to me. I did this for a couple of reasons. I was sick of searching for the international leader and, frankly, didn't find anybody that I felt was up to our needs and the caliber of leader that we wanted that really understood this space. But more importantly, as I learned over the length of time, I really wanted the emerging parts of the world to be attached to more mature markets so that the marketing team, the audience teams would be able to help impact the emerging markets, give them some of their advice and learnings. And also, to come back and be a flag bearer for what we need in the emerging markets, such as more speed and products that serve up in mobile. So instead of only one leader bringing that back to the product teams and to executive staff, that we actually have three leaders worry about emerging markets and being able to affect our business there.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Youssef Squali from Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Youssef Squali from Jefferies & Company.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, just quickly on Q1 guidance, how much Paid Inclusion revenues and cash flow would you say are your foregoing in that number since this is something you stop and start in January 1, I guess?  Your partner, Alibaba came out pretty boldly criticizing yo
componenttext: Tim, just quickly on Q1 guidance, how much Paid Inclusion revenues and cash flow would you say are your foregoing in that number since this is something you stop and start in January 1, I guess?  Your partner, Alibaba came out pretty boldly criticizing your position on the Google China issue. Carol, I was wondering if you could help us understand the nature of your relationship there beyond just being the passive shareholder and a long-term prospects for that relationship?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So we're going to continue with our practice of not breaking out individual products and certainly not their profitability. But I will say as I said earlier, we used to think going from fourth quarter to first quarter was probably about a 35 negative impa
componenttext: So we're going to continue with our practice of not breaking out individual products and certainly not their profitability. But I will say as I said earlier, we used to think going from fourth quarter to first quarter was probably about a 35 negative impact. Then I said, well now updated it looks like maybe more negative 30 or so. I would say the majority of that is that Paid Inclusion product. But again, I'm not going to break out cash flow and profitability by product.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Relative to Alibaba, we have a good relationship with Alibaba as we've said. We have an investment in Alibaba, Jerry sits on their board and really that's all there is to it.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeetil Patel from Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about revenues in O&O Search up 8% sequentially and overall, RPS of 8% sequentially and revenues were up about 5% in O&O Search. I guess 3% drop in click volume sequentially. I guess can you elaborate a little bit more about how that occurs whe
componenttext: You talked about revenues in O&O Search up 8% sequentially and overall, RPS of 8% sequentially and revenues were up about 5% in O&O Search. I guess 3% drop in click volume sequentially. I guess can you elaborate a little bit more about how that occurs when you've got the seasonal strength of the fourth quarter? Second, if you look at just the overall O&O display market, for you, what percentage of the growth in that business line will actually come from pricing versus compressions as you look forward?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, let me get the number and see what it was last quarter. Again, what you've seen is more of a focus for us certainly on the paid clicks and away from the toolbar distribution that we've spoken about a lot. Again, if you look at ou
componenttext: So on the first question, let me get the number and see what it was last quarter. Again, what you've seen is more of a focus for us certainly on the paid clicks and away from the toolbar distribution that we've spoken about a lot. Again, if you look at our volume, yes, I think it was down a little bit quarter-over-quarter let me try to put my finger on what it was third quarter to fourth quarter last year. We're focused on growing the volume which we did year-over-year and we're focused on RPS which increased quarter-over-quarter. So as we go forward as Carol said, we'll have browser upgrade offers and toolbar offers, homepage set offers, Messenger updates and toolbar goes along with that. We've got a lot of new products in there for the trending now which is really helping the top searches putting that maybe across the rest of the network, doing marketing on and off theYahoo! Network. So given what you've heard externally over the last few months, not a huge surprise what the volume is doing. I think what the good news is that RPS was up 8%.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Carol, you started to touch on this a little bit, but can you give us a sense of what you are seeing in engagement? We can obviously gauge this through comp score or Nielsen but there does seem to be a bit of a disconnect between what they're reporting an
componenttext: Carol, you started to touch on this a little bit, but can you give us a sense of what you are seeing in engagement? We can obviously gauge this through comp score or Nielsen but there does seem to be a bit of a disconnect between what they're reporting and some of the recent comments from Yahoo! We'd certainly appreciate your stance on that.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're actually encouraged by engagement, especially in some of our new areas like the Today module and obviously in Mail, some of our media properties. We're actually pretty excited about some of the things that are going to be coming out in video.
componenttext: Well, we're actually encouraged by engagement, especially in some of our new areas like the Today module and obviously in Mail, some of our media properties. We're actually pretty excited about some of the things that are going to be coming out in video. You know what I don't like -- what is hard to face into is the fact that people are still engaged in our site but they're also, of course, playing around on Facebook. I mean, they're engaged on Facebook. So as a percent you're seeing those numbers go up very fast. We're actually happy with the engagement we're seeing with us. We just can't keep up with that kind of engagement. Does that make sense? So what we've actually worked on and what's new for us, we are driving engagement and happy with that. We know that some of our sites need, obviously, sports and fantasy and so forth. Engagement with lifestyles, gossip, all of that, is really high. We've got less engagements, for instance, right now in science because last year they were hanging on the finance pages every second trying to figure out what was melting down. So when we think of integrating social, video, having a sort of a more multi-dimension experience, I think engagement's going to continue to grow for us.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just follow-up on Jeetil's question, too, because I finally found the number I was looking for. So last year, sequentially, eligible searches globally grew 3%, and this year they were down 3%. So it's not like 4Q is this huge barn burner usually. R
componenttext: Let me just follow-up on Jeetil's question, too, because I finally found the number I was looking for. So last year, sequentially, eligible searches globally grew 3%, and this year they were down 3%. So it's not like 4Q is this huge barn burner usually. RPS, yes, because you get more monetizable queries. But if you look at it, up three, down three, again, I would direct this to all of our efforts in improving volume going forward, and we're certainly very focused there.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's Mary also, so we each have a question. And if we can only have one, you guys can pick. So your Homepage is certainly becoming more relevant as measured by reach and usage, and advertisers have, obviously, noticed as you indicated that you had some so
componenttext: It's Mary also, so we each have a question. And if we can only have one, you guys can pick. So your Homepage is certainly becoming more relevant as measured by reach and usage, and advertisers have, obviously, noticed as you indicated that you had some sold out positions etcetera. At the same time, traditional content providers, the video and tech guys, are at the margin aiming to change the way they expand their distribution and monetize their content. A couple of recent examples are Fox and Comcast and also the focus on the Apple Tablet. And the question is, with all the video usage increasing that you have on the Homepage and the strong usage trends you have, is this attitude of the content providers, the traditional guys, good for you or bad for you?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, when we think of content, obviously, let me just kind of give a content hitch [ph] (1:02:48) because actually content is really very, very core to our strategy. When we think of a combination of original content, licensed content and links to th
componenttext: You know, when we think of content, obviously, let me just kind of give a content hitch [ph] (1:02:48) because actually content is really very, very core to our strategy. When we think of a combination of original content, licensed content and links to the best of the Web, and then our ability to optimize this to serve up the right mix for our user, including realtime content, I think we've been a good content partner, and I think you can go to most publishers and they will tell you that. We also have a good relationship, of course, with the newspapers and with AP and with Yellow Pages and whatever, Mary. I personally don't think as much as maybe Rupert, the fearless Mr. Jobs, think that this whole content thing is not going to switch overnight. A lot of content is not unique enough that unless everybody immediately goes to paid, a lot of content is not unique enough to have a special pay per value. We certainly know a content like the Wall Street Journal would be but normal news like Haiti content. I mean, Haiti content is all over. I think that what we like to do is optimize realtime on that content to add value. And that's what, of course, a lot of other media channels can't. So trust me, we're doing a lot of thinking of this in light of the Tablet, whatever it might be, in light of mobile, but I think there's a runway to figure this out. I don't think anything is going to flip overnight, next quarter, a quarter after that. And we're going to be in the mix because content is extremely critical to us.

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Scott. I just had one other question. The data in the quarter suggested that large online retailers grew double digits and small online retailers actually lost share, and Google suggested to cover points in its call that large advertisers outperfo
componenttext: This is Scott. I just had one other question. The data in the quarter suggested that large online retailers grew double digits and small online retailers actually lost share, and Google suggested to cover points in its call that large advertisers outperform small. So we're wondering if you could also just comment on ad spending trends by advertiser size in both Search and Display?

headline: Yahoo! Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what I will say in general because I don't think we go to that fine line. But when large advertisers come back into the mix, they come in with big dollars. So by definition, they can really put a pop on it. And especially when you have scarcity of h
componenttext: Well, what I will say in general because I don't think we go to that fine line. But when large advertisers come back into the mix, they come in with big dollars. So by definition, they can really put a pop on it. And especially when you have scarcity of high quality, high-reach inventory, which is what Yahoo! is, you're going to see the large guys with the money grab it. So that's without breaking down specific trends, that's logically you might imagine what we saw. Thank you, everybody. And we look forward to talking to you next quarter and see you at the Analyst Meeting in May.
